newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish coupon compensation scheme approved.
newsitem.headline: Polish coupon compensation scheme approved.

text.p: Poland's lower house of parliament on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a draft law compensating pensioners and public sector workers for overdue benefits and pay worth 6.8 billion zlotys ($2.6 billion).

Under the bill, adopted in a 420 to 0 vote with two abstentions, pensioners and public sector workers will get free coupons with which they can pay for state-held shares in various companies and some treasury-owned real estate.
The bill still needs to clear the senate and be signed by President Aleksander Kwasniewski.
The bill had been devised because Poland's budget could not afford to offer compensation in cash.

The state has to offer the compensation after the Constitutional Tribunal ruled in 1994 that previous governments had illegally curbed some pension and salary increases in 1990-1992, while trying to control the budget deficit.

The coupons, to be made available to more than nine million pensioners and public sector workers, will be exchangeable for shares which have been retained by the treasury in privatised companies that have been listed, sold to strategic investors or included in the mass privatisation programme.
The government will also earmark treasury-owned real estate to be bought with the coupons, called compensation certificates.
